_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RELEASE POLICIES
The MPLX- Lexington LP Terminal is a refined petroleum products terminal distributing product throughout the Lexington region including various grades of gasoline and distillates. The RMP-regulated process/stationary source is limited to the Butane Blending Process inclusive of a truck transport offloading station, a single pressure vessel, a pump, piping and various
appurtenances.

The Lexington LP Terminal is committed to operating and maintaining the Butane Blending Process in a safe, reliable and environmentally sound manner. MPLX believes that excellent performance in health, safety, and the environment goes hand-in-hand with operating reliably.

The Lexington LP Terminal is designed, operated, and maintained in a manner that protects the environment, as well as the health and safety of workers, contractors, and the community. This is accomplished through programs of awareness, compliance, prevention and protection. These programs include a combination of accidental release prevention, mitigation, and emergency
response planning. This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that MPLX and the Lexington LP Terminal have designed and implemented, including:
A. A description of the facility and the use of RMP-regulated substances (n-Butane);
B. An overview of the accidental release prevention programs (Program Level 3);
C. A five-year accident history for accidental releases of RMP-regulated chemicals;
D. An overview of the emergency response program; and
E. An overview of planned changes to improve safety.

A. STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES
The Butane Blending Process has been classified as Prevention Program Level 3. No Program 1 or 2 processes, containing RMP-regulated substances in excess of their respective threshold quantities, are identified.  By virtue of the flammable effects associated with butane, it is necessary to observe certain safety p

recautions during handling/storing to prevent unnecessary
human exposure, reduce the threat to employee health, and minimize potential impacts to nearby members of the community.  Safety at the Facility depends upon the manner in which butane is handled, as well as the various safety devices incorporated into the design of the process. Furthermore, comprehensive training is provided to employees which reinforces the safety policies and procedures of Lexington LP Terminal.

The facility maintains fixed inventories of Butane. Butane is received by truck (transports) and stored in one (1) storage vessel under pressure. The Butane is pumped to a metered, blending skid for direct injection into blend grade and premium unleaded gasoline lines feeding the site gasoline truck-loading rack.  Injection quantities are controlled via the blending skid utilizing auto-sampling for gasoline volatility properties. Process safety controls include vessel multiport pressure reliefs, excess flow valves, low-melting point fusible elements, fail-safe pneumatic control valves, fill protection/offload shutoff, manual emergency shut-off devices, and line thermal/hydrostatic (pressure) reliefs. The process is also monitored remotely "24/7". Access to the Lexington LP Terminal is restricted to authorized employees, management personnel and authorized contractors/visitors.

B. GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION MEASURES

The Lexington LP Terminal accidental release prevention and emergency planning/response programs help MPLX effectively manage the hazards posed by hazardous substances to its employees, the public, and the environment. The covered process is regulated by the EPA RMP regulation in 40 CFR Part 68, as well as the OSHA Process Safety Management standard 29CFR 1910.119.  The following accident prevention program elements are in place at the Lexington LP Terminal:

1) Employee Participation,
2) Process Safety Information,
3) Process Hazard

lease points,
-Hydrocarbon detectors at key process/perimeter areas to warn of a chemical release and automatically disable the process along with all terminal loading/offloading systems, and
-Vessel water monitor systems, and
-Remote secondary containment.

General Emergency Response

-Emergency alert system,
-Periodic emergency training for employees,
-Communication systems with local emergency responders and regulatory agencies,
-Emergency drills/exercises with terminal personnel, regulatory agencies, and community emergency responders to enhance response skills and coordination among agencies, and
-Mutual Aid with local fire departments.

Furthermore, the Lexington LP Terminal complies with the National Fire Protection Association's (NFPA's) Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) Code (NFPA-58) requirements for LP Gas storage and fuel blending. In addition to the presence of appropriate release prevention controls, a Facility Response Plan/Emergency Response Action Plan (FRP/ERAP or "Smart Plan") is in place with facility response activities being coordinated with the Lexington Fire Department and Lexington-Fayette Division of Emergency Management. Note that the Lexington LP Terminal is identified as a "non-responding stationary source" utilizing municipal 1st Responders for non-incipient stage fires and releases which cannot be handled within the scope of the site HazCom program.

C. FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The Lexington LP Terminal has an excellent record of accident prevention. The Terminal maintains records for all accidental chemical releases that occur at this facility. There have been no reportable accidents within the past five (5) years resulting from the release of materials as defined under the EPA RMP Rule.  Note that this is a new process anticipated to startup on or about April 1, 2025.

D. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

As previously noted, an FRP/ERAP or "Smart Plan" is in place to inform employees about what to do in case of a release and/or fire and to

notify emergency responders when there is a need for a response.

The Lexington LP Terminal maintains a relationship with the Lexington Fire Department and Lexington-Fayette Division of Emergency Management. Coordination events and notification exercises with members of local emergency response organizations are held every calendar year. These site tours, training and drills enable the public emergency responders to become familiar with Butane hazards, equipment, resources and personnel in the Terminal.

E. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

In an effort to improve and promote a process safety culture, the Lexington LP Terminal solicits employee input on process safety improvement ideas as documented in the MPLX Employee Participation Program. All process safety events (as defined in API 754) are electronically recorded, reviewed and investigated. The investigation may include a root-cause analysis (ex. TapRooT) per corporate policy depending on the nature and/or severity of the incident.
